intro: Gomphostemma eriocarpon, commonly known as the hairy fruit gooseberry, is a member of the Rubiaceae family. It is a shrub characterized by its small, elliptical leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in the spring. Its fruit is a small, fleshy berry that turns red when mature. Gomphostemma eriocarpon is typically found in moist woodlands and along stream banks in the southeastern United States.
